awd_titl_txt: Qualitative Properties of Solutions to Fluids Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses the solutions of partial differential equations modeling fluids. The principal goal is understanding the evolution of an incompressible fluid. In particular, the PI will study physical problems involving fluids with a free interface. This includes the motion of water waves, with or without surface tension, and a fluid-structure interaction problem. The PI will introduce techniques which shall advance our knowledge of fluids and promote further applications in science and engineering. Graduate students will be involved in all aspects of the project.

For the fluid structure interaction system, the research will seek a priori estimates leading to the local and long-time existence of solutions and the construction of solutions satisfying these properties. The PI will also study the qualitative properties of solutions, such as the persistence of analytic and Sobolev regularity, along with asymptotic behavior. Furthermore, the research seeks to answer similar questions for the solutions of the Euler equations with a free interface, focusing on the local existence and uniqueness of solutions. The PI will work on properties of solutions of other important models in connection with fluid dynamics, such as the 2D and 3D Boussinesq equations, active scalar equations, and the Prandtl equations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The project considered solutions to partial differential equations modeling fluids, with particular attention given to the Euler and Navier-Stokes equations, along with many related models. The project explored the motion of water waves with or without surface tension, regularity properties of solutions, fluid-structure models, analytic properties of solutions, and long-time behavior of solutions. The project also advanced knowledge on the local existence and global behavior of solutions for fluid-structure models, which are widely studied in engineering.


Intellectual Merit: The PI, along with collaborators, achieved the following results. On singular limits, the PI established the validity of the Euler+Prandtl asymptotic expansion for solutions of the Navier-Stokes equations as viscosity approaches zero. The expansion did not require higher-order corrections, as it evaluated the norm using an integrable norm in vorticity. Regarding Mach limits, the PI obtained results on the convergence of the compressible model toward the incompressible in strong Gevrey norms for Gevrey data. For fluid-structure interaction models, the PI obtained several local and global existence results. In particular, a new local existence result for the inviscid-plate fluid-structure model was achieved. For the deterministic Navier-Stokes equations, the PI established anisotropic criteria for their regularity. Other significant results include local existence for the stochastic Navier-Stokes equations, controllability results indicating when solutions to the MHD can be driven from one state to another, long-time convergence of solutions of the Boussinesq system, and a quantitative uniqueness property for a singular linear parabolic equation.


Broader Impact: Overall, five PhD students were involved in the project. Three have obtained their PhDs, one has defended her thesis, and one has started his research work toward his degree. The project included thirteen other collaborators. The PI co-organized three major conferences and three AMS special sessions. The PI and his students gave invited lectures on the project's results at many institutions and conferences.


Last Modified: 11/26/2023
Modified by: Igor Kukavica
